prior_works.title: A family of variable-metric methods derived by variational means
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Defines one of the four equivalent updates that constitute BFGS, providing the secant and positive-definiteness structure whose preservation under Armijo–Wolfe line search is central to the paper’s non-asymptotic analysis.

prior_works.title: Minimization of functions having Lipschitz continuous first partial derivatives
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the Armijo condition used in the Armijo–Wolfe line search; the paper’s per-iteration decrease and rate bounds are explicitly derived under this sufficient-decrease requirement.

prior_works.title: Convergence conditions for ascent methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the Wolfe curvature condition paired with Armijo to form the Armijo–Wolfe line search, which the paper leverages to control step sizes and enforce approximate secant behavior needed for global rate proofs.

prior_works.title: Nonlinear programming: computational methods (Zoutendijk's theorem)
prior_works.role: Global convergence framework for line-search methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The classical Zoutendijk framework under Armijo–Wolfe conditions underpins the transition from per-iteration decrease to global convergence; the paper refines this paradigm to obtain explicit non-asymptotic rates for BFGS.

prior_works.title: A characterization of superlinear convergence and its application to quasi-Newton methods
prior_works.authors: J. E. Dennis Jr., J. J. Moré
prior_works.role: Local superlinear theory for BFGS under Lipschitz Hessian
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the classic local superlinear convergence of BFGS given a Lipschitz Hessian; the new work globalizes and quantifies this behavior, deriving an explicit O((1/t)^t) superlinear rate and a condition-number–independent linear rate under Lipschitz Hessian.

prior_works.title: Some global convergence properties of a variable metric algorithm for minimization
prior_works.role: Early global convergence results for variable-metric/BFGS with inexact line search
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides seminal global convergence guarantees for variable-metric methods under Armijo–Wolfe–type searches; the present paper strengthens these by delivering the first explicit non-asymptotic global rates for classical BFGS.

prior_works.title: Greedy Quasi-Newton Methods for Convex Optimization
prior_works.role: Modern non-asymptotic analysis of quasi-Newton-type methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Develops explicit rate analyses for modified quasi-Newton schemes, highlighting the gap for classical BFGS; the new paper addresses this gap by establishing explicit global rates for unmodified BFGS with Armijo–Wolfe line search.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—first explicit, non-asymptotic global convergence rates for classical BFGS under Armijo–Wolfe line search—rests on three intertwined lines of prior work. First are the algorithmic foundations of BFGS itself (Goldfarb 1970), which define the secant structure and positive definiteness preserved by line-search implementations. Second are the line-search principles inaugurated by Armijo (1966) and Wolfe (1969), whose sufficient decrease and curvature conditions control step sizes and enforce meaningful progress; these conditions anchor most global analyses of line-search methods. Built on them is the Zoutendijk framework (1970), which connects Armijo–Wolfe steps to summability inequalities enabling global convergence arguments; the present work tightens this pathway to extract explicit per-iteration decrease and rates. The local behavior of BFGS is classically characterized by Dennis and Moré (1974), who proved superlinear convergence under a Lipschitz Hessian; this paper globalizes that local picture, deriving an explicit superlinear bound O((1/t)^t) and, when the Hessian is Lipschitz, a linear rate independent of the condition number, driven solely by line-search parameters. Powell’s early global results (1976) for variable-metric methods with inexact line searches provide the historical backdrop for global guarantees, which here are made quantitative and explicit. Finally, modern quasi-Newton analyses (Rodomanov and Nesterov, 2021) offered rates for modified updates, underscoring the open challenge for classical BFGS that this paper resolves by establishing global linear and superlinear non-asymptotic rates from arbitrary initialization.
